ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ELECTION OF PRESIDENT



    The following Question stood on the Order Paper:

    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam: To ask the Prime Minister when does he propose that Parliament should elect the next President for Singapore.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Questions for Oral Answer. Mr Jeyaretnam.

Column: 269



     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, this Question was asked before the announcement of the next President was made known in the papers on Monday. Now that the announcement has been made, I wish to withdraw this Question.

    But, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, on a point of order. May I ask a clarification from you about the sittings of Parliament.

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Yes, proceed.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, we were informed that Parliament would meet on the 4th of September this year. The Clerk of Parliament, as usual, sent out notices fixing the times for the submission of Questions and Notices to Parliament, and the last day for submission of Questions was the 24th of this month. Suddenly, after 5.00 pm on Friday, the 23rd, I had a notice saying that the sitting of Parliament has been brought forward to today. As a result of that, some seven Questions for Written Answer which I had proposed to send to the Clerk on the morning of the 24th, missed out. May I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, whether there were any compelling reasons for bringing forward the sitting of Parliament?

     Mr Deputy Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, that question is out of order. However, I would like to inform you that Standing Orders provide that Notice of Questions should be given not less than seven clear days. Your Question which was submitted on 24th August does not fall within the minimum number of days required under Standing Orders. Hence, it cannot be answered at this sitting.

RSAF PLANES LOST/DAMAGED IN FLIGHT


    2. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence if he will say how many Republic of Singapore Air Force planes were lost or damaged in flight in the week of the 21st to the 27th of July, 1985.

    The Minister of State for Defence and Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, two RSAF Skyhawk aircraft were lost

Column: 270

in flight during this period. The details have been reported in the press.

    The first incident occurred in the afternoon of 24th July 1985 over the Straits of Malacca. The pilot ejected safely.

    The second incident occurred in the morning of 25th July 1985 near Pulau Sarimbun in the Straits of Johor. The pilot was seen ejecting, but did not survive. His body was recovered three days later, after an intensive air and sea search.

    Since then, a third Skyhawk crash has occurred in the Philippines on 26th August 1985. The pilot ejected safely.

    As far as can be determined at present, the causes of the three crashes are unrelated. However, as a precaution, after the third accident, the RSAF has temporarily grounded all its Skyhawk aircraft for thorough technical inspections. The Skyhawks will resume flying once these checks are completed and they are certified safe.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I have a few supplementary questions for the Minister of State. First of all, I see that there are Boards of Inquiry that had been appointed. May I ask again whether the findings of these Boards of Inquiry will be made public or, if not, at least released to the Members of this House?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as has been explained in this House before, the findings of Boards of Inquiry are privileged documents and will not be made public.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, may I know on what grounds are they privileged?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Board of Inquiry proceedings are privileged, following British practice, for two reasons. Firstly, legal difficulties, because witnesses appearing before a Board of Inquiry are not protected by the same rules of evidence which, apply in the Courts. Secondly, because there could, in some cases, be security objections. It is not parliamentary practice to release Board of Inquiry's findings and reports.

Column: 271



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, does the Minister of State not realize that he has not answered my question? May I ask him why is it necessary to follow the British practice? Secondly, may I ask him: does he not realize that all the answers that he has given are completely irrelevant and evasive?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson may yet regret his supplementary question. We follow British parliamentary practice when it makes good sense to do so.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Minister of State has said that these three crashes were unrelated, but that the planes have been grounded. May I ask for an assurance from the Minister of State that if it is found that these crashes were due to mechanical defects in these planes, or they had not been airworthy at the time that they were taken to the air, that finding will be made public?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Such findings shall be made public as it is in the public interest to make public.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, is the Minister of State satisfied that the track record of the RSAF is satisfactory as compared to other air forces?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Deputy Speaker,Sir,l think the RSAF has a reasonable, indeed good track record, Over the last five to ten years, the RSAF has expanded rapidly and dramatically. The numbers of pilots, numbers of aircraft, amount of flying, all have practically doubled. During this period, we have seen also a corresponding improvement in the accident rate of RSAF aircraft. To ask what has happened within one week or one month, and to conclude that something must be wrong for five years or ten years, is a typical example of searching for the irrelevant fact and coming out with the wrong answer.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister of State not realize that there were two crashes about a year ago? Also, the same planes, I believe, Now, my next question for the Minister of State is this: if these planes were found to be defective - that

Column: 272

there were some mechanical defects in them - would the family of the pilot who lost his life be paid adequate compensation as is provided for under the law where an employee in a private employment loses his life as a result of any negligence in the equipment or in the care taken over his safety?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in all cases, SAF personnel are paid adequate compensation.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister of State not realize that under the SAF (Pensions) Regulations, all that his family will get, besides pension for the widow, is a year's salary? But if he is in the private sector, the dependants, the family of the person in these circumstances, will get much more, far more than is provided for under the SAF (Pensions) Regulations.

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Anson feels that the Pensions Regulations are inadequate, then we should have a debate on the Pensions Regulations. I believe today's question is on the accidents.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, does the Minister not realize that the answer lies in repealing Section 14 of the Government Proceedings Act which would then enable a serviceman, who loses his life as a result of any negligence, either in the equipment or in the inadequate care taken for his safety, to bring an action in our courts and claim the full measure of damages?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I think this has been debated before, and the then Minister for Defence, now also the First Deputy Prime Minister, has explained why it is not practical for the Armed Forces to be in a position where it can be sued by individuals. In war, there are a myriad circumstances in which a person may be injured or lose his life, and it would be impossible for the Government to deal with the millions of claims afterwards. It is against standard practice and it is nothing new.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Minister of State seriously suggesting that we are in a situation of war at the moment?

Column: 273

    The Singapore Sports Council will consider floodlighting sports complexes at HDB estates should there be a need to do so.

RED SWASTIKA AND YU NENG PRIMARY SCHOOLS
(Pre-primary classes)


    5. Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam asked the Minister for Trade and Industry and

Column: 274

Minister for Education whether he will consider increasing the number of pre-primary classes in Red Swastika Primary School and Yu Neng Primary School in Bedok North Estate as there is a pressing need for more places.

    The Minister of State for Education and Communications and Information (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Education): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    The number of pre-primary classes in Red Swastika School and Yu Neng Primary School cannot be further increased because there are no more classrooms to take in additional pre-primary children.

    My Ministry's priority at this time is to meet the demand for places of children seeking admission to Primary One. Red Swastika School and Yu Neng Primary School are both situated in Bedok. In 1984, 876 Primary 1 places out of a total of 4,050 places in the primary schools in Bedok were left for registration under Phase 3. This year, only 436 Primary 1 places were left for Phase 3. If we were to increase the number of pre-primary classes in the two schools concerned, we would have to correspondingly reduce the already tight supply of Primary 1 places in Bedok area.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Sir, would the Minister of State agree to look into the possibility of meeting this need in the future?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir.

     Maj Fong Sip Chee (Kampong Chai Chee): Sir, does the Minister realize that in the Red Swastika School there is no provision for the Malay language subject in the pre-primary class? Which means that when the pre-primary students were to be registered for Primary 1 the following year, no non-Chinese student can be admitted under the scheme in that school, so that the school will forever be a school without any Malay student.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, it is not true that a school which has pre-primary intake will not have places at Primary 1 for pupils who are coming to join the school not through the pre-primary intake. All the

Column: 275

schools that have pre-primary classes also have places at Primary 1 level for direct intake at Primary 1. I believe that the Red Swastika School will be one of these schools.

     Maj Fong Sip Chee: Sir, does the Minister realize that his answer betrays knowledge on the subject? The Red Swastika School happens to be a school that would take in directly Primary 1 cohorts from the pre-primary school. And if there is no Malay language as a subject in the pre-primary classes, then there would not be any Malay students in that school in the future.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, I will look into this particular school. As a rule, schools which have pre-primary classes have an intake which will go on to Primary 1. But the Primary 1 classes in these schools will have vacancies for those who are coming in on direct intake into Primary 1 as well.

     Maj Fong Sip Chee: I thank the Minister for his confession of ignorance on the subject.

PASAR MALAM


    6. Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked the Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Education whether he is satisfied that the "pasar malam" at the Singapore Handicraft Centre is a success and, if so, whether he will consider a scheme to designate more "pasar malam" areas so as to provide a wider variety of interest for tourists as well as more opportunities for our small businessmen.

     The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Dr Wong Kwei Cheong) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry and Minister for Education): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am answering this question on behalf of my Minister.

    The pasar malam at the Singapore Handicraft Centre was introduced by the Singapore Tourist Promotion Board in April this year. It operates every Friday, Saturday and Sunday from 4 pm to 10 pm and also on Wednesdays from 6 pm to 10 pm. A total of 81 stallholders and demonstrators of vanishing trades operate at the pasar malam. Items sold include works of art, handicrafts and souvenirs. In addition,

Column: 276

on-the-spot art demonstrations and handicraft making demonstrations are also featured. To complement the pasar malam activities and create a festive atmosphere, cultural and contemporary entertainment are also regularly featured.

    In our assessment, the pasar malam at the Singapore Handicraft Centre has been a success. Firstly, it is a good crowd drawer. The average number of visitors to the pasar malam is estimated at 1,200 per day during weekends and around 400 on weekdays. Tourists account for between 20-25% of visitors. Secondly, many visitors, especially tourists, have expressed satisfaction with the pasar malam as they find it a unique style of shopping. They seem to enjoy the bargaining and haggling.

    Finally, the stall holders themselves have indicated their satisfaction with the pasar malam. In fact, they have requested the STPB to extend the pasar malam activities to other tourist spots. The STPB is now actively working with the Ministry of the Environment to identify other suitable locations for pasar malam activities. This will provide a wider variety of attractions for tourists as well as more business opportunities for our smaller businessmen.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Jalan Kayu): Sir, would the Minister of State consider extending the times of operation at the pasar malam at the Handicraft Centre to other days of the week?

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: We will consider the extension to other days of the week as and when business improves and if more people come to these pasar malam activities.

The architect is presently working towards complying with these requirements, after which tenders will be called for the renovation works to begin.

The question I wish to ask is: can these renovation works be expedited because the mosque is now in a bad state of disrepair?

SECTION 149 OF COMPANIES ACT

My Ministry is currently studying the matter in consultation with the Attorney-General's Chambers, the Registry of Companies and Businesses, as well as interested business and professional bodies.

USE OF CPF SAVINGS FOR CHILDREN'S EDUCATION


    10. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Acting Minister for Labour, as the Government is considering allowing Central Provident Fund savings to be used for various forms of investments, whether he will also consider allowing CPF savings to be used for children's education such as tertiary education or specialised technical/professional training which is a form of capital investment.

     The Acting Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, this question was raised in the last budget debate. My reply then was that we should first look at other alternatives, such as more liberal granting of scholarships and bursaries as well as the possibility of providing interest-free loans to those who qualify for admission to our universities. This way we avoid eating into the low CPF savings of many parents who require the savings for their own financial security and for home ownership. This basically is still my position. We should not lose sight of the priorities of the CPF scheme which are to provide members with financial security and to enable them to own their homes.

Column: 279

These priorities must first be met before we consider other possibilities.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Sir, will the Acting Minister consider the use of CPF savings for the contributors' own education in approved courses?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, my answer will apply to that situation as well,

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether he would consider certain arrangements which would help to alleviate the concern he has about the need to safeguard that there are enough savings for old age? For example, the amount that can be used for education can be limited to a certain percentage; or if the parent has used his CPF fund for the child's education, then later on when the child starts work he will be required to pay back that portion of the CPF from his own CPF contributions.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I think the better approach would be to try not to touch the CPF savings if there are other alternatives. My position is that we should bear in mind the priorities. Having done so, and if they are satisfied, then we can look at other possibilities.

     Mr Tang See Chim (Chua Chu Kang): Sir, if the CPF holder is now allowed to buy a second property with his CPF, why can he not use his CPF for the education of his children? And what better protection for old age than a well educated child who is prepared to look after the parents in their old age!

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am not saying that we will not consider the various possibilities. I am saying that we will have to bear in mind the priorities and if they are satisfied, then we will look at other possibilities.

     Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, is the Minister going to look into it right away, or just saying this and forgetting about it afterwards?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: There is a committee in my Ministry which is looking into the CPF question, and we will look at the various possibilities.

Column: 280



     Maj Fong Sip Chee: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, this is an old question. From the answer given by the Minister on the question of priority, I would ask the Minister whether he would agree that at this moment the priority is to allow members to own a second property rather than allowing them to use the extra money for the education of his children. Does the Minister agree that in the situation where a member has no alternative, instead of putting the money in the CPF deposit he would rather use it to acquire a second property, since he cannot use it for his children's education? May I ask the Minister whether he has got his priorities correct?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, the answer is yes, we have got our priorities correct. The difference between investment in properties and education is, of course, that you are in fact transferring the benefit of the latter to another person. I am not saying that education is not a form of investment. It is. But there are various alternatives available, such as the one suggested by the former Minister for Finance, like interest-free loans. I think this should really be looked into because the CPF savings of a lot of the older members are, in fact, quite low. For example, about 68% have less than $20,000 each in their CPF balance.
